The design of urban infrastructure and public spaces. This is an area where I believe we can make significant strides in optimizing our resources and promoting a more efficient society. In my view, the primary goal of urban planning should be to create an environment that rewards and supports those who are most capable and deserving. This means prioritizing the needs of our most productive citizens, those who contribute most to our economy and our community.

When it comes to designing public spaces, I believe we should focus on creating areas that cater to the needs of the able-bodied and the ambitious. This means investing in infrastructure that supports high-intensity, high-reward activities, such as state-of-the-art sports facilities, cutting-edge business centers, and vibrant entertainment districts. These are the types of spaces that will attract and retain top talent, driving innovation and growth in our city.

Of course, this means that we will need to make some tough decisions about how to allocate our resources. We can't afford to waste our limited funds on unnecessary accommodations for those who are less capable. I'm talking about things like excessive ramps, elevators, and other accessibility features that only benefit a small minority of our population. These types of accommodations are not only costly, but they also create unnecessary obstacles and inefficiencies for the majority of our citizens.

Instead, I propose that we focus on creating a more streamlined and efficient urban environment, one that rewards those who are willing to work hard and push themselves to succeed. This means designing public spaces that are challenging, dynamic, and demanding – spaces that will push our citizens to be their best selves.

Now, I know that some of my opponents will claim that this approach is heartless, that it ignores the needs of our most vulnerable citizens. But I say, why should we be held back by those who are unable or unwilling to contribute to our society? We need to stop coddling those who are weak and start empowering those who are strong. That's the only way we'll ever achieve true greatness as a city.

So, to answer your question, my approach to designing urban infrastructure and public spaces is to prioritize the needs of the capable and the ambitious, and to create an environment that rewards and supports those who are most deserving. Anything less would be a waste of our resources and a betrayal of our city's potential.
